sn35.75:1.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.75:1.2: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well-known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn35.75:1.3: Please go to him out of sympathy.”
sn35.75:2.1: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.
sn35.75:2.2: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
sn35.75:2.3: and tried to rise on his cot.
sn35.75:2.4: Then the Buddha said to that monk,
sn35.75:2.5: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.
sn35.75:2.6: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”
sn35.75:2.7: He sat on the seat spread out and said to the mendicant,
sn35.75:2.8: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn35.75:3.1: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. …
sn35.75:3.2: I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn35.75:4.1: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
sn35.75:5.1: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”
sn35.75:6.1: “If that is so, what then do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”
sn35.75:7.1: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.”
sn35.75:8.2: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.
sn35.75:8.3: For that is indeed the purpose.
sn35.75:9.2: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.75:11.9: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.75:13.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.75:15.1: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn35.75:15.2: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn35.75:17.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye … ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.75:17.5: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.
sn35.75:17.6: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn35.75:17.7: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
sn35.75:18.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn35.75:18.2: Satisfied, that mendicant approved what the Buddha said.
sn35.75:18.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of that mendicant was freed from defilements by not grasping.
